titleStmt.title: Persian MS 648
titleStmt.funder: Iran Heritage Foundation and The John Rylands Research Institute

msContents.summary: This incomplete copy of ʿĀshiq u Maʿshūq (Lover and Beloved), alternatively entitled >Hamīshah Bahār (Eternal Spring), originally composed in 1051 AH (1641-42 CE), by the poet Fānī Kashmīrī (d.1081 AH/1671-2 CE). It features a prosimetric allegorical narrative following the adventures of a prince named Buland Akhtar, as he travels through Kashmir in search of the meaning of love, and encounters kings, dervishes, fairies and ogres along the way..

msItem.author: Fānī, Muḥsin, -1671 or 1672 فانى كشميرى، محسن بن محسن
msItem.title: ʿĀshiq u Maʿshūq musammā bi-Hamīshah bahār
ʿĀshiq u Maʿshūq, otherwise known as Hamīshah bahār
عاشق و معشوق مسمی به همیشه بهار
msItem.explicit: برگ ۱۳۳ر (folio 133a): زآنکه هم نام هم نشان فانیست تمت بالخیر نسخه عاشق و معشوق مسمی به همیشه بهار بوقت نیک صورت اتمام پذیرفت
msItem.note: Previously misidentified as a copy of Ikhlāṣ Chand's taz̲kira Hamīshah Bahār (Eternal Spring), James White correctly identified the work's main title as ʿĀshiq u Maʿshūq (Lover and Beloved), the author as Fānī given on folio 133a, and the date of completion given in a chronogram on folio 132a, top, that equals 1051 AH (1641-42 CE). On the basis of the name, date, and contents, the work can be ascribed to the poet Fānī Kashmīrī (d. ca. 1672 CE).

supportDesc.support: Thin, straight and cross-grained, buff-coloured paper handmade in the Indian subcontinent, with >1mm between laid lines, and no discernible chain lines. Some folios dyed pale pink and peach.
supportDesc.foliation: Foliated with pencilled Arabic numerals by the cataloguer on the upper left of each a side.
supportDesc.collation: Undetermined. Catchwords throughout on the lower left corners of the b sides.

condition.p: Good condition, albeit lacking the initial folio(s), and with extensive historical repairs throughout.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 1 column with 13 lines per page. Ruled with a misṭarah hand guide.

handNote.desc: Written in black nasta'līq with subheaders and poetic genres in red titles, nasta'līq with shikastah ligatures.
Arabic quotations written in black naskh.

binding.p: Likely rebound in Delhi for former owner George William Hamilton after his appointment as Commisioner in 1863.

Sewn on a single support put down on the inside of the pasteboards, edges trimmed, with twined Islamic-style chevron endbands in green and red silk. Covered in full smooth polished red goatskin leather, with squares and defined joints, but without a flap (type III binding per Déroche).
binding.decoNote: Spine and board margins dyed black, ‌‌‌with strips of green paper applied as inner margins, tooled with a foliate arabesque design, and ruled with single yellow lines. This same tooled decoration also appears on Rylands Persian MS 572 and 631A paper label on the spine bears the title Nuskhah-'i Hamīshah Bahār.
binding.condition: In good condition, albeit tightly bound with restricted opening to the gutter.

history.origin: Probably completed in the Indian subcontinent; undated, but likely early 19th century.

provenance.p: Subsequently acquired by Colonel George William Hamilton (1807-1868) who served in India from 1823 to 1867, latterly as Commissioner in Delhi. He acquired over a thousand Indian and Persian manuscripts, from which the British Museum selected 352, now held in the British Library.

history.provenance: Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880) purchased the remainder of Hamilton's collection in 1868.

provenance.p: Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript catalogue by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s, concisely published as Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript correctly identified and described by James White with reference to the volume in 2017.
Record subsequently, corrected, augmented, and enhanced by Jake Benson in 2022 with reference to the volume in hand.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.
